text: Hi there! With people at JuliaConstraints org (only a few months old ^^), we consider submitting for a birds of feather session. Unfortunately, I haven't joined one yet, so I am a bit lost on how to organize the proposal. Is the mentor thing available for birds of feather?

text: Sure. Talk to me. I am not on the committee this year.

elements.text: Sure. Talk to me. I am not on the committee this year.

text:
In general BoF are super laid back.
They are the un-talk to match an un-conference.
In a physical conference, they are about giving chairs and a  table to the kind of chat that normally happens in the corridor.

elements.text:

In a physical conference, they are about giving chairs and a  table to the kind of chat that normally happens in the corridor.

text:
A good BoF submission IMO:
1. Actually fills in the submission. (We rejected a few in the last few years who didn't and tried to rely on the name and established nature of there subcommunity to swing it. Which I think is kinda legit, but it's a losing bet to the submission that actually fills in)
2. Has something that indicates who should attend. E.g "All are welcome, but this BoF is primarily targetted at Developer and experienced users of FooBar"

3. Has indication of what will be covered/focused on, and any outputs in that will be produced

4. Is actually wanting to use the BoF. For  a round table discussion. Not a talk, or a series of talks.
